pageTitle: Live Reporting | $100,000 Super High Roller | 2013 PokerStars Caribbean Adventure | PokerNews
TableContextTimeStampBeforeTable: {8268=Scott Seiver Wins the 2013 PokerStars Caribbean Adventure $100,000 Super High Roller ($2,003,480)}
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {13057=The next batch of players to be eliminated included Timothy Adams, Tobias Reinkemeier, Bertrand “ElkY” Grospellier, and Benefield. Grospellier was crippled in a massive pot with Vivek Rajkumar before moving all in with two sixes. Fabian Quoss had him at risk with , and the board ran out , eliminating ElkY from play., 16994=At this point, Sands took over. He won a 1.4 million-chip race against Rajkumar – Rajkumar busted shortly after – and then he tangled with Phil Ivey in a massive, near three million-chip pot. With the blinds at 12,000/24,000/3,000, Sands opened to 57,000 from early position, Ivey defended his big blind, and the flop fell . Ivey checked, Sands continued for 64,000, and Ivey called., 39428=From Day 1 To Day 7: Tracking the Progress of the Final 27 in the 2015 WSOP Main Event, 9493=Day 2 began with 37 players. Jeff Gross and David Benefield re-entered before the start of play, taking that number to 39, and the final number of entries was 59. The prize pool ($5,724,180) is the second largest in the history of $100,000 super high rollers – the 2012 PokerStars and Monte-Carlo® Casino EPT Grand Final SHR generated a prize pool of €4,432,500 (roughly $5,790,840)., 40540=The Online Railbird Report: Blom's Wild July Ride; A High-Stakes Baby Expected & More, 39750=Phil Ivey Arrives at the 2015 WSOP: "I Care About Bracelets, But Duty Calls"}
textBeforeTable: The board ran out , and Esfandiari was eliminated. Here’s how the official final table looks: Sands: Esfandiari: Nearly 30 minutes later, the $228,960 bubble burst with the elimination of Antonio Esfandiari. Esfandiari opened to 90,000 from early position with the blinds at 20,000/40,000/5,000. Sands three-bet to 170,000 on his direct left, Esfandiari moved all in for around 850,000, and Sands quickly called. Team PokerStars Pro Jason Mercier, who had his aces cracked by Troyanovsky earlier in the day, bubbled the unofficial final table. Schulman jammed for effectively 375,000 from the small blind, and Mercier snapped it off in the big blind. Schulman had , which crushed Mercier’s , and the board came out . Selbst showed
textAfterTable: The final table will begin tomorrow 1 p.m. EST, where the eight remaining players will battle it out for the $2,003,480 first-place prize, and a shiny new trophy. The PokerNews Live Reporting Team will be covering all the action, so make sure to check out the Live Reporting Page.
